soc.message

Class SOCChoosePlayer

  • java.lang.Object
    • soc.message.SOCMessage
      • soc.message.SOCMessageForGame
        • soc.message.SOCChoosePlayer
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable

    public class SOCChoosePlayer
extends SOCMessageForGame
    This message from client to server has a few purposes, all related to robbing:
    • In response to a server's SOCChoosePlayerRequest, it says which player the current player wants to steal from.

      In some game scenarios in version 2.0.00 or newer, the player might have the option to steal from no one. If the player makes that choice, getChoice() is CHOICE_NO_PLAYER.

    • In response to a server's SOCGameState (WAITING_FOR_ROBBER_OR_PIRATE) message, it says whether the player wants to move the robber or the pirate ship. (v2.0.00+)
    • In response to a server's SOCChoosePlayer message, it says whether the player wants to rob cloth or rob a resource from the victim. (v2.0.00+)
    getChoice() gets the client's choice.

    Server will respond with the results of the choice: SOCReportRobbery, SOCGameState, etc.

    Also sent from server to client (v2.0.00+) in game state WAITING_FOR_ROB_CLOTH_OR_RESOURCE to prompt the client player to choose what to rob from the victim (cloth or a resource); getChoice() is the victim player number.

    Author:
    Robert S. Thomas <thomas@infolab.northwestern.edu>
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • SOCChoosePlayer

        public SOCChoosePlayer(java.lang.String gameName,
                       int ch)
        Create a ChoosePlayer message.
        Parameters:
        gameName - the name of the game
        ch - the number of the chosen player, or CHOICE_NO_PLAYER to choose no one, or CHOICE_MOVE_ROBBER to move the robber or CHOICE_MOVE_PIRATE to move the pirate ship.
        For WAITING_FOR_ROB_CLOTH_OR_RESOURCE, use ch = playerNumber to rob a resource from that player; to rob cloth, use ch = -(playerNumber + 1).

    • Method Detail

      • getChoice

        public int getChoice()
        Returns:
        the number of the chosen player, or CHOICE_NO_PLAYER to choose no one, or CHOICE_MOVE_ROBBER to move the robber or CHOICE_MOVE_PIRATE to move the pirate ship.
        For WAITING_FOR_ROB_CLOTH_OR_RESOURCE, getChoice() >= 0 means rob a resource from that player number, and getChoice() < 0 means rob cloth from player number (-getChoice()) - 1.

      • toCmd

        public java.lang.String toCmd()
        CHOOSEPLAYER sep game sep2 choice
        Overrides:
        toCmd in class SOCMessageForGame
        Returns:
        the command string

        public static SOCChoosePlayer parseDataStr(java.lang.String s)
        Parse the command String into a ChoosePlayer message
        Parameters:
        s - the String to parse
        Returns:
        a ChoosePlayer message, or null if the data is garbled

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Description copied from class: SOCMessage
        Simple human-readable delimited representation, used for debug purposes: SOCPutPiece:game=test5|playerNumber=3|pieceType=0|coord=40a
        Could also be used by a SOCServer.recordGameEvent(String, SOCMessage) implementation.

        Within this representation, message parameters should be in same order used by SOCMessage.toCmd() and parseDataStr(..). Should be parseable by SOCMessage.parseMsgStr(String) which calls SOCMessage.stripAttribNames(String), which your class can override if needed.

        Overrides:
        toString in class SOCMessageForGame
        Returns:
        a human readable form of the message
        See Also:
        SOCMessage.toCmd()
